Of all USA's shows I currently watch (Burn Notice, Royal Pains, Covert Affairs), Covert Affairs is probably my favorite. While Burn Notice is still fun, it just seems to be a rehash every season of the same story with different people, much like Heroes ended up doing. Covert Affairs stars Piper Perabo as a shoe-in CIA Agent - or so she thinks. Her entry into Langley as a field agent is suspect from the beginning of the season as her one-time love interest, Ben Mercer, keeps popping up (in more ways than one) to haunt her. Is she there because of her talent? That's up for you to decide. Annie's sidekick, August "Auggie" Anderson, is a blind, tech savvy, ex-soldier who makes a great partner for Annie and can seemingly get more women than Brad Pitt. Annie's superiors, constantly feuding husband and wife duo Joan and Arthur Campbell, make for an interesting side story in each episode with Joan being Annie's direct boss and head of the DPD and Arthur being Joan's boss and Director of Clandestine Services (DCS). Another recognizable face is that of Sendhil Ramamurthy, a.k.a. Mohinder Suresh from Heroes.

I don't want to say Covert Affairs is unique however it does give us, what I would consider, a good look into the methods of the CIA. Annie is constantly being chosen for dangerous field ops and always gets into tight situations where she, very MacGuyver like, always manages to find a way out. One thing that bothers me about this show and it is an issue with all three above mentioned USA shows is that you can predict that: a). with Royal Pains, Hank always seems to be around when someone's health is hitting the fan b). in Burn Notice, Michael is supposed to be incognito yet word gets around and people always seem to know what he does, where he lives, and how to reach him and c). with Covert Affairs it seems like in every episode, Joan tells Annie, "Don't do this without my approval" and she does it anyways. Joan will tell Arthur, who has just chosen Annie for the umpteenth time to do a dangerous op, "I will not put Annie in danger again" yet next episode, like clockwork, we're in a pickle again. I realize this nitpicky but this is why I gave it a 4 instead of a 5. Someone above mentioned "This will never be Lost or 24 caliber." To you I say it is USA. This is as good as it is going to get on a network that sells its shows as character driven and that's what Covert Affairs is.

I was very disappointed by the quality of acting in this series.  That said, I really enjoy being able to download an episode or two through video on demand and try out the series. Whew, saved me buying a series which I did not enjoy.

First, what type of looks does the CIA like its people to have?  Stunningly beautiful?  Super ugly?  No.  Those kinds of people draw attention.  The CIA likes people who blend in with a crowd, who people look right past without noticing them.  So why is everyone on this show good looking?  I know, it's not supposed to be realistic, it's TV.

Second, our lead gal got selected for her language skills and didn't even finish her initial training.  She has no fighting skills and is always being thrown around by her opponents.  Yet she almost always wins her fights against better trained, bigger, stronger opponents.  Again, not realistic, just TV.

That being said, I love this series.  It's fresh and fun.  The leading lady, Piper Perabo as Annie Walker, is very likeable and sympathetic.  But the real star of the show is Christopher Gorham as Auggie Anderson.  He is believable, likeable, and the viewer instantly feels a connection with him.  These two are the show, but "Auggie" is the best. Watching the chemistry between the two of them and watching Auggie work his magic is worth the price of admission, regardless of the storyline.

So, not realistic, but fun, and well worth watching.

The 2 seasons are mildly entertaining. If you're looking for realistically staged espionage, this isn't it. There's eye candy galore and you have to accept that female CIA field operatives wearing 4 inch heels can outrun the average terrorist and that in the office they all wear skin-tight sheath dresses (designer, of course) and can afford all that & the swankiest addresses in the nation's capital on a government salary. But in all fairness, the plot lines improve tremendously in seasons 3 & 4 and Piper Perabo seems less one dimensional. Maybe she's a better actress than the first 2 seasons would suggest. Perhaps she just needed better material. None of the actors are terrible, but none are stellar, either. With the exception of the actor who plays Henry Wilcox, the arch villain of the series, who burns up the screen with his treachery, menace, and all around evil. He doesn't go as hammy as Spader in Blacklist. He never crosses the line into camp, but goes right up to the edge to wonderful effect. He's a joy to watch.

Halfway through the first episode, it was clear that the character doesn't speak a lick of any of the "six languages" she is apparently fluent in. The actress could have done so much better than "zdrast-voo-tee" for "Hello" in Russian (listen to any YouTube video or Google Translate to hear how "" should sound). And her life spent backpacking around the world and "helping refugees in Somalia" just made her look like a rich white savior. She looks good in a skirt, but she is very unlikable.

I don't know how I missed this show during its original run. I'd never heard of it before until discovering it on Prime Video a couple of nights ago. I get the premise, the CIA gets the ol' USA Network "light hearted" treatment. But the amount of on her knees, hands behind the back brown nosing to authority our heroine does here is just a bit revolting. The CIA is not only Daddy, but Mommy too!

The press are evil. Secrets kept from us dumb sheep (the american people) are good things. Being one of the young, hip, above the law, super-alpha insiders of the CIA is something to aspire to!

Most of this era of USA shows struck me as workplace fantasies for millennials which mined similar territory. Your boss cares about you! (He doesn't). Work is fulfilling because you get to wear great clothes! (it isn't, you don't). By being part of the corporate world makes you a 1 percenter! (hahahaha).

Lets face it, white collar work is dying behind a desk, but yeah its TV fantasy. Still this particular TV fantasy has a few too many sour authoritarian notes to it. My god whatever happened to the American spirit of pragmatic patriotism, and respect for authority tempered with a good dose of skepticism? It's nowhere on offer in Covert Affairs. The world it presents to viewers is that if you get good grades, work out enough, and you're hot, you get to be a master of the universe too! After a rookie year of suitably light hearted hazing by people who secretly love you, you join their higher class of people who are above the law.

If this is something you even fantasize about, there's a crucial piece missing in your character.

The USA Network television series "Covert Affairs" is a thoroughly entertaining and enjoyable combination of an exciting espionage thriller, and an engaging interpersonal drama. This first season follows the exploits of Annie Walker, an intrepid young CIA operative, who demonstrates intelligence and wisdom beyond her years, in her pursuit of the successful completion of her designated missions. "Covert Affairs" features superb writing, acting, and plot development, and the performances of the lead actors, Piper Perabo and Christopher Gorham, are truly exceptional. "Covert Affairs" is an outstanding television series, and I give its first season a five-star rating, along with my highest recommendation.

She's a CIA trainee who gets an emergency field promotion and learns to work through the politics of "the community."  Without going into details or spoilers they tried several sub-plots over the seasons and several minor characters that changed over the course of the run.  They also changed title intros in the last few years.  Also in those last years they did season long main plots in which each episode resolved nicely.  Annie didn't even get a gun until later in the series!  They tried out several love interests but that didn't make the show run.  It was the people at CIA and Annie that made the show run.  It was Augie as her handler.  Joan as her friend and mentor.  Joan's husband Arthur and foreign spy Eyal Levine are part time "community" members helping her.  These are the people you root for and watch for.  Every episode is worth seeing.  The pilot sets the mood showing what Annie and the show are all about.  People who like shows like Alias, 24, Quantico will probably like this show as well!

I watched the first two episodes and couldn't get past how ditzy and needy this woman was.  I was hoping for James Bond but with a woman.  Perhaps, she grows into the character I wanted to see, but I really really struggled taking Piper's role as Annie Walker seriously.  I actually felt her role and that of all the women in the show seemed very demeaning.  Annie's first mission in the CIA is to pretend to be a prostitute, hmmm?  All the guys at the CIA are constantly ogling her, borderline harassing her if it weren't for the fact that she allows harassment to continue and rolls with the flirtation game...I'm sure the feminists are thrilled with this.  She clings to every man with more experience (which is literally everyone since she is the rookie) and begs them for help because she is apparently incapable of figuring anything out on her own (some great CIA training).  She doesn't have any confidence despite supposedly being at the top of her class.  Unbeknownst to her, she only in fact got recruited into the CIA because of her connection with a former boyfriend, because all good women needed a man to get them in at some point, right?  Then, she gets her ass kicked in her first two fights before being saved by a man in each instance.  After two beat-downs she has a blind CIA agent (his character is literally blind, though I think he's more like Daredevil each time I see him, with the attuned senses) teach her how to fight because the CIA hand to hand combat training is supposedly useless (?!?) and being taught by a blind veteran who's a lady's man is much better.

Again for the feminists to chew on, there's some sort of side story going on with Annie's boss, involving her paranoia that her husband is cheating on her.  She uses CIA assets to stalk him, and is is of course proven wrong.  He's completely innocent and she is just a crazy, jealous, needy woman???  Mind you, there is NO backstory to help me understand why she suspects her husband of cheating, apparently this is just what women do anytime a man logs phone calls with a woman.  WTF

On the personal life side we find another strong female character.  Annie's sister is not allowed to know she is in the CIA and this is the whole reason why the two of them seem to have a complicated relationship, not because of any real backstory drama between the two.  The sister is completely bi-polar too...the 13 year old version of it.  She is super whiny in one scene blaming Annie for everything and then all apologies with no explanation for the change in heart during the next scene.  I really can't handle the change in character without explanation from one scene to the next.  Let's develop the sister so that I understand what the heck is going on with this stuff, otherwise, I'm just annoyed by her childishness.  Two episodes, ready to move on to something I can take seriously.

I'm actually giving this two stars for desired potential if we just had some writers from the 21st century who could develop a female character before shoving her in a skirt and throwing her on screen because she's hot and there are CIA action scenes.  There are in fact elements to build upon within the plot, Piper seems like an actress with potential and she's certainly enjoyable eye candy for those of us that are interested.  The story seems like it could become intriguing.  Unfortunately for me, with the inexplicable portrayal of the female characters, it's not enough to throw an attractive body at the problem and call it solved, but what do I know, this thing was on TV for five seasons. I want to preface this by saying that I have not been a regular tv watcher since I was a teenager, except for the occasional Masterpiece Theater and documentary.  I started watching Covert Affairs because it was included with Prime and sounded like a fun diversion.  It hooked me from the start and I watched all 5 seasons within about 2 months.
Why do I love this show?
a)  Strong female protagonist who is brave and brilliant, intrepid and audacious.  But she has need of a learning curve for doing her job.  We learn along with her.  Annie Walker is a great role model -- she is true to her values throughout:  compassion, loyalty to friends especially.  This show should be required watching for all teenagers, especially girls.  That being said, we watch her evolve into someone who is top of her game yet pays a high personal price:  increasing isolation, losing loved ones, (spoiler alert:) even losing her health.  Yet, in the end, thanks to the fine writing and production team, in spite of the dark turn to the series, Annie seemingly winds up exactly where is best for her  with a stellar man and a career wide open, true fulfillment all dependent on her next choices.
b)  The acting and production values are superb.  The lead characters and even the recurring ones are believable and the development of their characters feels real.  We also get to trot around the globe with them.  Its a wild ride at times.
c) In spite of the descent of most tv into the realm of near-porn, there is no T & A in this series, not even serious swearing.  It should come as no surprise that suspense, realism, entertainment, and true engagement can be had without cheap devices, if the writing, acting, directing, and timely context are top notch.  Is there sex?  You betcha.  But its not graphic at all  no real nudity, so if thats what a viewer is looking for, look elsewhere.  The sex is also within the context of relationships within the storyline  it is not gratuitous.
d) A wonderful recurring Israeli Mossad character.  Its time mainstream media painted such a positive picture now and then.
e) Not sure how realistic a portrayal of the CIA it is, but its very good at depicting territorial squabbling between US governmental agencies, the high stakes game of low-level diplomacy, the hardly crystalline reputation of US ops abroad and at home, and the threats to peace, life and limb, big and small, that are truly out there at all times.  The viewer gets swung into the middle of all this at a breakneck pace because we not only care for the outcome, we care about the characters involved  the ones in the field and the ones behind a desk.

All that being said, heres what I didn't love:
- More than a few of the plots and the sequences of events are simply preposterous.  The logic at times was thin indeed.  Even the movements of characters from point A to B boggled the mind.  Still, one gets caught up in the storyline and the tensionand its not a documentary, after all.  By the same token, the aftereffects of the physical knocks the characters take are hardly realistic -- would have liked to see better makeup and continuity. Is that asking too much?
- A thoughtful, more rounded Annie becomes, over time, hard-edged and virtually lacking in introspective ability.  Perhaps this is how shes able to be nimble, riding her instincts and brilliant mind, and, also the price she pays.  It might indeed have been a good time to end the series with Season 5 for this reason.  After this she could only become a cartoonish character, a kind of Wonderwoman making all the right action hero moves.

What a surprise to see that this series doesn't have more 5-star reviews. I'm giving it that rating, I think justifiably. To be sure, when I first started watching (just a few weeks ago, long after the entire thing had run its original course) I was somewhat diffident about the show. I wasn't sure I much cared for the basic premise; in the real world, the CIA has screwed up a LOT of things, resulting in a lot of needless suffering and waste (and damaged U.S. standing in the world). I don't hate those folks, and I do appreciate the dangerous and often vital work they do (as any sensible person ought to), but have mixed feelings. So anything that glorifies the Agency vaguely annoys me just on principle.

Nor was I much sure I cared for the lead, actress Piper Perabo, who initially struck me as a lightweight.

Wrong. She's a wonderful actor, deeply talented, as watching two seasons of the show (so far) clearly demonstrates. And after a couple of episodes, I found I'd fully suspended disbelief about the CIA and the show's premise (perhaps a little easier thanks to the show's plausible treatment of both the people there and the institution's normal operating procedures). Add to that a very strong cast overall -- Peter Gallagher and Kari Matchett are skilled old hands, while Christopher Gorham (new to me) is simply terrific.

And one more thing: the production values of the show are really marvelous. In ways big and small, this series comes amazingly close to capturing the feel of the real world, and the real people in the world, in every episode. So often TV feels too much like the product of a sound stage. The sense of reality in this show, by contrast, is impressive. Since the central premise -- Incredible Days in the Life of a CIA Agent -- pushes hard on disbelief, enveloping it with big-budget film production details makes a huge difference.

Is there anything worth down rating the show for? Well, honestly, the stories themselves. They are not bad, not at all. The writing is consistently plausible, and entertaining. But none of the stories have been magical, either. They're good, solid, craftsmanlike, but they don't have you on the edge of your seat or jumping up and down like the very best of TV can do. (To cite an example, the first two or three years of Burn Notice, a show otherwise not nearly as plausible). Nor is there the kind of heavy complexity and character development that you find in many British productions. It most assuredly feels like an American production end to end.

But if spy capers appeal to you, this show should be on your Watch List. It's beautifully done, and worth your time.

The writing and acting in this series is superb. I had never heard of the show, but am now hooked on it. Have watched my way thru the first 2 seasons (30+ episodes) and am now starting Season 3.

Some things to be aware of: Each episode in the series is almost always a single CIA assignment. Many of the nuances involved in the story are complicated and you have to remember them in order for the story to make sense. For that reason, it's best NOT to start an episode for the first few minutes, then quit, thinking you'll resume tomorrow. By tomorrow, you will probably have forgotten some of the critical things revealed in the first part of the video.

There are some things that don't make much sense. The main character, Annie Walker, falls in love with or gets very involved with various men from episode to episode, but the relationships never go anywhere. Some of the men just disappear; that is, the man she was involved with in the preceding episode just never appears again. No explanation. She is also obviously in love with Augie, her perennial guide and protector in the Agency, but nothing more than big smiles and now-and-then hugs ever happen. It will be interesting to see where that relationship goes in the last season. Annie also gets herself into many life & death situations, but is never armed. Given the kinds of danger some events pose, I don't believe a real CIA operative would go into them unarmed.

Piper Perabo kicks butt! Wonderful first season with a cast that meshes very well. Season's story develops Piper's CIA persona as a real person, in what could be real situations while attempting to deal with family as well. She's two people and the conflict starts to show by the end of the season.

Since I am addicted to all the other shows on the USA Network, I put Covert Affairs on my DVR sight unseen.  It also helped that the show was being called a cross between Alias and Chuck, two shows I absolutely love.  While it didn't quite live up to that hype, I found myself hooked on the show by the time the first season ended.

The show centers around Annie Walker (Piper Perabo), a new recruit at the CIA.  She is pulled from training early and begins her field work.  Her new boss is Joan Campbell (Kari Matchett) who just happens to be married to CIA director Arthur (Peter Gallagher).  There are sparks between her and her two co-workers, Jai Wilcox (Sendhil Ramamurthy) and the blind Auggie Anderson (Christopher Gorham).

Her first case finds Annie trying to retrieve secrets from a Russian only to have him shot by a sniper while she is in the room.  From there, she tries to help a mother and son who have uncovered a coded IRA message, keep a senator's mistress from taking the fall for stolen secrets, and help an Iranian defect to the US through Niagra Falls.

What Annie doesn't realize is that the CIA wants her in the field because they are trying to flush out Ben Mercer (Eion Bailey).  Ben and Annie met and had a steamy affair before he vanished.  In the years since, Annie hasn't quite gotten over him enough to be ready to move on.  Why did Ben leave without a word?  What is the CIA's interest in him?

As I implied in the first paragraph, I wasn't hooked right from the start.  The show introduced too many storylines.  There was nothing wrong with any of them, but I needed time to get to know the characters first.  For example, it's established in the pilot that Joan and Arthur have marital problems.  At that point, I didn't care.  Each episode has a main story and then brings in one or two of the storylines and advances them.  Again, it would have helped if they'd have fewer stories to juggle so they could have advanced the story in every episode.  By season two, the multiple storylines wouldn't have been the issue for me that it was here.

The main episode of each week is always fun and interesting.  Annie is still very inexperienced, so watching her get into and out of some pretty hairy experiences is always entertaining to watch.  I found the storyline with Ben fascinating and couldn't wait to find out what exactly was going on with him and why the CIA wanted to get in touch with him so much.

Most of the characters developed nicely, too.  Annie is smart and resourceful, as she should be since she's the lead character.  Jai has some interesting family relationships that come into play as the season progresses.  We rarely see beyond Joan's business exterior, even with the marital troubles she has with Peter.  But the most interesting character is Auggie.  They really develop him in interesting ways.  When I found out in the pilot that he was blind, I didn't think he'd ever leave the office, but they managed to find ways to show him in all kinds of environments.  Next to Annie, he's the best character on the show.

The actors do a fine job bringing their characters to life each week.  I've read some complaints at Piper's performance as Annie, but I always find it believable.

The only weak spot when it comes to characters is Annie's sister Danielle, played by Anne Dudek.  Danielle really has nothing to do except try to flesh out Annie's character.  She does that at times, although their sub-plots are usually the most predictable of any episode.  That's no disrespect to Anne Dudek; she just doesn't have much to work with.

I should mention that the show lives up to its name.  There are several steamy scenes.  It doesn't get beyond PG-13 range, but there is definitely more content like that than anything else that USA Network has done to date.

The first season of the show consisted of eleven episodes, and they are presented here on 3 DVD's in their native wide screen and full surround.  Extras include a few behind the scenes featurettes, a gag reel, a set tour, deleted scenes, and three commentaries.  And, in a nice touch, the DVD's contain descriptive services for the visually impaired.  I don't think I've even seen that on a DVD before, and considering one of the characters is blind, it's a great tie in.

I'm glad I gave the show a chance to grow on me because I got hooked on the first season of Covert Affairs.  If you enjoy spy stories, be sure to check this one out.

I was disappointed with this show.  I was expecting a strong heroin and instead was forced to watch the most incompetent spy to ever lead a series.  As a fan of this genre, I expected a strong lead female character in the vein of  La Femme Nikita, Nikita, Alias, even Dollhouse, but found myself watching a character who goes out of her way to suck at her job, get caught, and be rescued EVERY SINGLE EPISODE!  She consistently breaks her cover or is discovered while keeping secrets from her friends and family (the people who she should trust and confide in) while divulging national secrets to complete strangers in an effort to "win their trust", or some BS like that.  The show is thoroughly unbelievable even as fantasy, and the main character, Annie Walker, is a complete disaster.
  Don't get me wrong though, the actors were great and do a phenomenal job portraying their characters, but the writers should have been replaced after season 1.  They decided to create a character who was a SPY who can't lie, falls in love with EVERY asset she encounters, has the hand-to-hand skills of a 4 year old (she literally gets beat up every episode), and the trade-craft of Johnny English.  I dredged through the series in hopes to find that her character grew, but instead she just got worse every episode, to the point that I could anticipate the plot after the first 10 minutes of the episode. Here it goes...
SPOILER: An event happens, she gets briefed, the seasoned professionals come up with a plan, but she comes up with an unorthodox way to accomplish it, they "give her a chance".  She meets an asset.  She finds the "good" in the asset, causing her to compromise the mission and fail.  The Seasoned Professionals come up with a contingency plan, or decide to scrub the mission.  She disagrees, goes off book and tries to finish the mission anyway.  This fails, she has to be broken out of jail or rescued by a blind guy or a deus-ex-machina old acquaintance.  The asset is saved and she goes back to work, praised for her cunning, "instinct", and stick-to-it attitude.  Wash, rinse, repeat...  Take my word for it, EVERY EPISODE is exactly like this.  I dare anyone to find a single episode that isn't.
  Ultimately, I felt like I lost several hours of my life and should have spent the time finally watching Breaking Bad or at least re-watching Nikita or Fringe.  If you can manage through the first season, then this is for you, but if you are annoyed by the end, trust me, it just get exponentially worse as it continues.  So sad.

This show is very unique, it was ahead of its time when it first aired, before the current trend of spy shows.  It's part spy show, part chic-lit novel, at least for the first three seasons, it takes a more serious turn in the beginning of season 4 and that continues through to the ending.  It has action and intrigue, but also a very down to earth look at the CIA through the eyes of the main characters.  This show ran for five seasons, and it was very consistent throughout, always improving, always finding a new angle to explore.  It was a lot of fun to binge watch and I enjoyed watching it again, I recommend this show to anyone looking for a more mild (by today's standards) yet still exciting and action filled spy show.
